original_data.question: A 20-year-old woman in the army recruit collapses during an especially hot day at basic training. She was in her normal excellent state of health prior to this event. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory infection (URI) but has since recovered. Her father has chronic kidney disease (CKD), bilateral hearing loss, and vision problems. At the hospital, her temperature is 40.3°C (104.5°F), blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical exam, the patient appears to have altered mental status and her skin is dry, hot, and erythematous. She is complaining of severe bilateral flank pain and generalized myalgia. Catheterization produces 200 mL of tea-colored urine. Urine dipstick is positive for blood, but urinalysis is negative for RBCs or WBCs. Which of the following is most likely responsible for her condition?

options.A: A mutation of the COL4A5 gene

model_response:
The patient is suffering from a heat stroke. Heat stroke occurs when body temperature regulation fails, resulting in dangerously high body temperature. Heat stroke can be exercise-induced or caused by exposure to high environmental temperatures. The patient's altered mental status, dry skin, and myalgia are consistent with this diagnosis. The tea-colored urine is due to myoglobinuria, which occurs when muscle breakdown products (including myoglobin) are released into the blood and filtered by the kidneys. The absence of RBCs or WBCs in the urine suggests that rhabdomyolysis, rather than a urinary tract infection, is the cause of the myoglobinuria. The patient's father has features suggestive of Alport syndrome, which is caused by mutations in the COL4A5 gene. Neisseria meningitides can cause meningitis, which presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. IgA nephropathy can cause hematuria and proteinuria, but usually follows an upper respiratory infection. The patient's symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Occurring or done each day.
To teach with hands-on experience
The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.
Earlier in time or order.
Something that happens at a given place and time.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An infectious process affecting the upper respiratory tract (nose, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, or trachea). Symptoms include congestion, sneezing, coughing, fever, and sore throat.
An infectious process affecting the upper respiratory tract (nose, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, or trachea). Symptoms include congestion, sneezing, coughing, fever, and sore throat.
Male parents, human or animal.
Impairment of the renal function secondary to chronic kidney damage persisting for three or more months.
Impairment of the renal function secondary to chronic kidney damage persisting for three or more months.
Partial hearing loss in both ears.
Sight that is impaired.
Institutions with an organized medical staff which provide medical care to patients.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Removal of moisture from a substance (chemical, food, tissue, etc.).
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Painful sensation in the muscles.

Use or insertion of a tubular device into a duct, blood vessel, hollow organ, or body cavity for injecting or withdrawing fluids for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. It differs from INTUBATION in that the tube here is used to restore or maintain patency in obstructions.
Liquid by-product of excretion produced in the kidneys, temporarily stored in the bladder until discharge through the URETHRA.
Use of a test strip designed to detect one or more specific substances in urine. Results are indicated by a color change and may be qualitative or semi-quantitative.
Involving advantage or good.
The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.

Examination of urine by chemical, physical, or microscopic means. Routine urinalysis usually includes performing chemical screening tests, determining specific gravity, observing any unusual color or odor, screening for bacteriuria, and examining the sediment microscopically.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.
White blood cells. These include granular leukocytes (BASOPHILS; EOSINOPHILS; and NEUTROPHILS) as well as non-granular leukocytes (LYMPHOCYTES and MONOCYTES).
A state of being, such as a state of health.
